solution_line_template: In the first route, Malcolm spends {uphill_walk_time} minutes * {path_multiplier} = <<{uphill_walk_time}*{path_multiplier}={path_walk_time}>>{path_walk_time} minutes walking along the path.
So in total, the first two stages of this route take him {uphill_walk_time} + {path_walk_time} = <<{uphill_walk_time}+{path_walk_time}={first_two_stages_time}>>{first_two_stages_time} minutes.
This means the final part of the journey took him {first_two_stages_time} / {final_stage_divisor} = <<{first_two_stages_time}/{final_stage_divisor}={final_stage_time}>>{final_stage_time} minutes.

Therefore, the total time it takes to walk the first route is {first_two_stages_time} + {final_stage_time} = <<{first_two_stages_time}+{final_stage_time}={total_first_route_time}>>{total_first_route_time} minutes.

In the second route, the second stage takes him {flat_path_time} * {second_stage_multiplier} = <<{flat_path_time}*{second_stage_multiplier}={second_route_second_stage_time}>>{second_route_second_stage_time} minutes.

So the second route takes a total of {second_route_second_stage_time} + {flat_path_time} = <<{second_route_second_stage_time}+{flat_path_time}={total_second_route_time}>>{total_second_route_time} minutes to walk.

The second route therefore takes an extra {total_second_route_time} minutes for the second route - {total_first_route_time} minutes for the first route = <<{total_second_route_time}-{total_first_route_time}={time_difference}>>{time_difference} minutes.
